title: Army Pauses Ajax Vehicle Use Due to Health Concerns
summary: The British Army has temporarily halted the use of Ajax armored vehicles following reports of soldiers falling ill from excessive noise and vibration during a military exercise. Approximately 30 personnel experienced symptoms such as vomiting and shaking after training on Salisbury Plain, prompting an investigation by the Ministry of Defence. This incident occurs despite recent assurances from defence minister Luke Pollard that the £6.3 billion program had overcome its challenges and achieved initial operating capability. The Ajax vehicles, manufactured by General Dynamics in Merthyr Tydfil, Wales, have been plagued by delays and prior issues with noise and vibration injuring soldiers. A 2023 review identified systemic problems within the MoD and errors in the project's management. With over 160 vehicles built out of a planned 589, the two-week pause aims to address safety concerns while limited testing continues to identify and resolve faults. Full operational capability is still years away, highlighting ongoing struggles in this high-cost defence initiative.

background_read: The Ajax armoured vehicle programme is a major UK defence project initiated to replace older vehicles, with a total cost of £6.3 billion. It has faced significant delays since its start, originally scheduled for 2019, due to issues like noise and vibration that have previously injured soldiers. The Ministry of Defence oversees the project, and a 2023 review pointed to institutional failures. Understanding this context helps explain why the current pause is part of a longer history of challenges, emphasizing the importance of safety and proper management in large-scale military investments.
